This is the young friend of whom I spoke to you. His inclination to cultivate your art is very strong, and he has in- -telligence, quickness of perception, and it appears to me an uncommon- -ly correct eye for outline.

Still painters are so very numerous, that I hardly know whether to advise him to cherish his inclina- -tion, or not. I wish you would be as candid and friendly with him, as you would have liked to have had an artist of reputation with you, in the days of your small beginnings.
At all events, please let him come in and look at your pictures, whenever it is convenient for you both; and give him any hints that may be useful.

Yrs truly, L. M. Child. P.S. I am surprised and grieved at Colt's verdict. It is the effect of an infuriated and blood-thirsty populace. Nothing in the trial sustains the charge of premeditated guilt. It was most unquestionably the frenzy and reck- -lessness of blind rage at the mo- -ment. The editors of the Penny papers are, to say the least, as guilty as he. God forgive them! Whether they know it or not, they are mur- -derers, and they make murderers.
Letter to Samuel Stillman Osgood, n.d.
